description.full: ofxCvFloatImage is an image class that represents the values of each color of each pixel as float values, on a scale of 0.0 - 1.0. They are a more precise but heavier (i.e. requiring more memory) way representing the data in an image. Keep in mind though that most of the image operations in OpenCV expect a grayscale image, which you can construct using the ofxCvGrayscaleImage. If you're loading image data from another image you might want to check what image scale is being used with the image to ensure that you don't get your scales wrong.

methods.name: addWeighted
methods.parameters: ofxCvGrayscaleImage &mom, float f
methods.desc: Copies the pixel data of an ofxCvGrayscaleImage into the pixel data of the ofxCvShortImage.

methods.name: allocatePixels
methods.parameters: int w, int h

methods.name: clear
methods.desc: Remove all pixel data from the ofxCvFloatImage instance.

methods.name: contrastStretch
methods.desc: This increases the contrast of the image remapping the brightest points in the image to 255 and the darkest points in the image to 0.

methods.name: convertFloatToGray
methods.parameters: int *floatImg, int *grayImg

methods.name: convertGrayToFloat
methods.parameters: int *grayImg, int *floatImg

methods.name: convertToRange
methods.parameters: float min, float max
methods.desc:
Maps the pixels of an image to the min and max range passed in.


second.convertToRange(100, 140); // super low contrast

methods.name: flagImageChanged
methods.desc: Flag whether the image pixel data has changed so that the ofTexture can be updated.

methods.name: getFloatPixelsRef
methods.desc: Returns a ofFloatPixels that contains the pixels of the image.

methods.name: getNativeScaleMax
methods.desc: If you've set the native scale max and min using setNativeScale() this returns the maximum value.

methods.name: getNativeScaleMin
methods.desc: If you've set the native scale max and min using setNativeScale() this returns the minimum value.

methods.name: getPixelsAsFloats
methods.desc: Returns a pointer to an array of floating point numbers that represent the pixels of the image.

methods.name: getRoiFloatPixelsRef
methods.desc: Returns a ofFloatPixels that contains the pixels within the ROI the image.

methods.name: getRoiPixelsAsFloats
methods.desc: Returns a pointer to an array of floating point numbers that represent the pixels of the ROI of the image.

methods.name: ofxCvFloatImage
methods.desc: Constructor.

methods.name: ofxCvFloatImage
methods.parameters: const ofxCvFloatImage &mom
methods.desc: Copy constructor.

methods.name: operator&=
methods.parameters: ofxCvImage &mom
methods.desc:
Binary & (Logical AND http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitwise_operation) the pixel data of the right hand side image from the current image:

cvPuppy.allocate( 320, 240 );    
cvPuppy = puppyImg.getPixels(); // copy pixels from a loaded image
    
andPuppy.allocate( 320, 240 );
    
andPuppy.set(255, 0, 0); // make the AND image red
andPuppy &= cvPuppy; // will & all the bits

methods.name: operator*=
methods.parameters: float scalar
methods.desc:
Multiplies the pixel data of the right hand side image from the current image:

first *= second; // both are ofxCvFloatImage instances

methods.name: operator*=
methods.parameters: ofxCvImage &mom
methods.desc:
Multiplies the pixel data of the right hand side image from the current image:

first *= second; // both are ofxCvFloatImage instances

methods.name: operator/=
methods.parameters: float scalar
methods.desc:
Divides each pixel of the pixel data of the right hand side image from the current image:

first /= second; // both are ofxCvFloatImage instances

methods.name: operator=
methods.parameters: unsigned char *_pixels
methods.desc: Copy the data from an array of unsigned char numbers into the ofxCvFloatImage instance. The dimensions of the array are assumed to match the dimensions of the image. The values will be converted to a 0.0 - 1.0 scale.

methods.name: operator=
methods.parameters: float *_pixels
methods.desc: Copy the data from an array of floating point numbers into the ofxCvFloatImage instance. The dimensions of the array are assumed to match the dimensions of the image.

methods.name: operator=
methods.parameters: const ofxCvGrayscaleImage &mom
methods.desc: Copy the data from an ofxCvGrayscaleImage image into the ofxCvFloatImage instance.

methods.name: operator=
methods.parameters: const ofxCvColorImage &mom
methods.desc: Copy the data from an ofxCvColor image into the ofxCvFloatImage instance.

methods.name: operator=
methods.parameters: const ofxCvFloatImage &mom
methods.desc: Copy the data from an ofxCvFloatImage image into the ofxCvFloatImage instance.

methods.name: operator=
methods.parameters: const ofxCvShortImage &mom

methods.name: operator=
methods.parameters: const int *mom

methods.name: resize
methods.parameters: int w, int h
methods.desc: Resizes the image to the w.h passed in.

methods.name: scaleIntoMe
methods.parameters: ofxCvImage &mom, int interpolationMethod
methods.desc:
Scales the image passed in to be the size of the current image,


ofxCvImage first;
first.allocate(640, 480);
ofxCvImage second;
second.allocate(320, 240);

second.scaleIntoMe(first); // first is now 320,240

methods.name: set
methods.parameters: float value
methods.desc: Set all the pixels in the image to the float value passed in. This is useful for blanking or filling an image quickly. the values are 0.0 to 1.0.

methods.name: setFromPixels
methods.parameters: const unsigned char *_pixels, int w, int h
methods.desc: Set all the pixels in a ofxCvGrayscaleImage from a pointer to an array of unsigned char values, using the w and h parameters to determine the dimensions of the image. The array is assumed to contain color values.

methods.name: setFromPixels
methods.parameters: float *_pixels, int w, int h
methods.desc: This allows you to set the ROI on the image from an array of pixels. Region of Interest is a rectangular area in an image, to segment object for further processing. Once the ROI is defined, OpenCV functions will operate on the ROI, reducing the number of pixels that the operation will examine.

methods.name: setNativeScale
methods.parameters: float _scaleMin, float _scaleMax
methods.desc: Allows you to set the native scale of your images, for instance, if your images contain values ranging from 0.0 to 255.0 (unlikely, but possible) then you would want to set them to ensure that all image operations complete correctly.

methods.name: setRoiFromPixels
methods.parameters: const unsigned char *_pixels, int w, int h
methods.desc: This allows you to set the ROI on the image from an array of pixels. Region of Interest is a rectangular area in an image, to segment object for further processing. Once the ROI is defined, OpenCV functions will operate on the ROI, reducing the number of pixels that the operation will examine.

methods.name: setRoiFromPixels
methods.parameters: float *_pixels, int w, int h
methods.desc: This allows you to set the ROI on the image from an ofPixels instance. Region of Interest is a rectangular area in an image, to segment object for further processing. Once the ROI is defined, OpenCV functions will operate on the ROI, reducing the number of pixels that the operation will examine.

page.document:
#class ofxCvFloatImage

##InlineDescription

##Description

ofxCvFloatImage is an image class that represents the values of each color of each pixel as float values, on a scale of 0.0 - 1.0. They are a more precise but heavier (i.e. requiring more memory) way representing the data in an image. Keep in mind though that most of the image operations in OpenCV expect a grayscale image, which you can construct using the ofxCvGrayscaleImage. If you're loading image data from another image you might want to check what image scale is being used with the image to ensure that you don't get your scales wrong.

cvPuppy.allocate( 320, 240 );

_inlined_description: _

_inlined_description: _

_description: _

ofxCvImage first;
first.allocate(640, 480);
ofxCvImage second;
second.allocate(320, 240);

second.scaleIntoMe(first); // first is now 320,240

###void set(value)

_inlined_description: _

_description: _

Set all the pixels in the image to the float value passed in. This is useful for blanking or filling an image quickly. the values are 0.0 to 1.0.

###void setFromPixels(*_pixels, w, h)

_inlined_description: _

_description: _

Set all the pixels in a ofxCvGrayscaleImage from a pointer to an array of unsigned char values, using the w and h parameters to determine the dimensions of the image. The array is assumed to contain color values.

###void setFromPixels(*_pixels, w, h)

_inlined_description: _

_description: _

This allows you to set the ROI on the image from an array of pixels. Region of Interest is a rectangular area in an image, to segment object for further processing. Once the ROI is defined, OpenCV functions will operate on the ROI, reducing the number of pixels that the operation will examine.

###void setNativeScale(_scaleMin, _scaleMax)

_inlined_description: _

_description: _

Allows you to set the native scale of your images, for instance, if your images contain values ranging from 0.0 to 255.0 (unlikely, but possible) then you would want to set them to ensure that all image operations complete correctly.

###void setRoiFromPixels(*_pixels, w, h)

_inlined_description: _

_description: _

This allows you to set the ROI on the image from an array of pixels. Region of Interest is a rectangular area in an image, to segment object for further processing. Once the ROI is defined, OpenCV functions will operate on the ROI, reducing the number of pixels that the operation will examine.

###void setRoiFromPixels(*_pixels, w, h)

_inlined_description: _

_description: _

This allows you to set the ROI on the image from an ofPixels instance. Region of Interest is a rectangular area in an image, to segment object for further processing. Once the ROI is defined, OpenCV functions will operate on the ROI, reducing the number of pixels that the operation will examine.

##InlineDescription






##Description

ofxCvFloatImage is an image class that represents the values of each color of each pixel as float values, on a scale of 0.0 - 1.0. They are a more precise but heavier (i.e. requiring more memory) way representing the data in an image. Keep in mind though that most of the image operations in OpenCV expect a grayscale image, which you can construct using the ofxCvGrayscaleImage. If you're loading image data from another image you might want to check what image scale is being used with the image to ensure that you don't get your scales wrong.

###void operator&=(&mom)

<!--
_syntax: operator&=(&mom)_
_name: operator&=_
_returns: void_
_returns_description: _
_parameters: ofxCvImage &mom_
_access: public_
_version_started: 007_
_version_deprecated: _
_summary: _
_constant: False_
_static: False_
_visible: True_
_advanced: False_
-->

_inlined_description: _







_description: _

Binary & (Logical AND http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitwise_operation) the pixel data of the right hand side image from the current image:

~~~~{.cpp}
cvPuppy.allocate( 320, 240 );    
cvPuppy = puppyImg.getPixels(); // copy pixels from a loaded image
    
andPuppy.allocate( 320, 240 );
    
andPuppy.set(255, 0, 0); // make the AND image red
andPuppy &= cvPuppy; // will & all the bits 
~~~~

![puppy AND](ANDoperation.png "Using the &= operation")

###void scaleIntoMe(&mom, interpolationMethod)

<!--
_syntax: scaleIntoMe(&mom, interpolationMethod)_
_name: scaleIntoMe_
_returns: void_
_returns_description: _
_parameters: ofxCvImage &mom, int interpolationMethod_
_access: public_
_version_started: 007_
_version_deprecated: _
_summary: _
_constant: False_
_static: False_
_visible: True_
_advanced: False_
-->

_inlined_description: _







_description: _

Scales the image passed in to be the size of the current image, 

~~~~{.cpp}

ofxCvImage first;
first.allocate(640, 480);
ofxCvImage second;
second.allocate(320, 240);

second.scaleIntoMe(first); // first is now 320,240

~~~~

-->

Set all the pixels in the image to the float value passed in. This is useful for blanking or filling an image quickly. the values are 0.0 to 1.0.

_version_deprecated: _
_summary: _
_constant: False_
_static: False_
_visible: True_
_advanced: False_
-->

_inlined_description: _







_description: _

Set all the pixels in a ofxCvGrayscaleImage from a pointer to an array of unsigned char values, using the w and h parameters to determine the dimensions of the image. The array is assumed to contain color values.





<!----------------------------------------------------------------------------->

###void setFromPixels(*_pixels, w, h)

<!--
_syntax: setFromPixels(*_pixels, w, h)_
_name: setFromPixels_
_returns: void_
_returns_description: _
_parameters: float *_pixels, int w, int h_
_access: public_
_version_started: 007_
_version_deprecated: _
_summary: _
_constant: False_
_static: False_
_visible: True_
_advanced: False_
-->

_inlined_description: _







_description: _

This allows you to set the ROI on the image from an array of pixels. Region of Interest is a rectangular area in an image, to segment object for further processing. Once the ROI is defined, OpenCV functions will operate on the ROI, reducing the number of pixels that the operation will examine.





<!----------------------------------------------------------------------------->

###void setNativeScale(_scaleMin, _scaleMax)

<!--
_syntax: setNativeScale(_scaleMin, _scaleMax)_
_name: setNativeScale_
_returns: void_

_parameters: float _scaleMin, float _scaleMax_
_access: public_
_version_started: 007_
_version_deprecated: _
_summary: _
_constant: False_
_static: False_
_visible: True_
_advanced: False_
-->

_inlined_description: _







_description: _

Allows you to set the native scale of your images, for instance, if your images contain values ranging from 0.0 to 255.0 (unlikely, but possible) then you would want to set them to ensure that all image operations complete correctly.
